weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus numbers have put Australia's growth factor back above one — should we be worried?
weeklyTopNews.summary: For the first time in more than a month, the 'growth factor' for COVID-19 cases in Australia has risen above one - it is currently 1.04. That is, there are more new cases this week than there were last week. Put simply, growth factor is a measure of how quickly the number of new cases is rising or falling — and the critical thing to remember is that we want to keep it below one. Catherine Bennett, the chair of epidemiology at Deakin University, says that the importance of this number at this stage in the outbreak is really as a signal that something's changed over the last seven days and what we expect that to be now is probably clusters of cases. She stated that this means that we've got work to do — we've got to make sure that the reason it's above one is well under control.

weeklyTopNews.title: Covidsafe app is not working properly on iPhones, authorities admit
weeklyTopNews.summary: Australians running the COVIDSafe contact tracing app on iPhones may not be recording all the data required if they don’t have the app running in the foreground or they are using an older model phone, the government has admitted. More than 5.1 million Australians have downloaded and registered to use the app on iPhone and Android devices, and, while the Android version works while running in the background (ie, not open on the screen), the iPhone version works best when the app is open on the screen and the phone is unlocked.

weeklyTopNews.title: WA marks one week without new coronavirus cases
weeklyTopNews.summary: Western Australia has marked one week of no new COVID-19 cases, as the state government expands a study testing asymptomatic people. Only 14 active cases remain in the state, including seven patients in Perth hospitals, while 528 people have recovered. Premier Mark McGowan stated that while the state government was focused on loosening restrictions that would boost the economy and keep people safe, the hard border closure would remain in place for now.

weeklyTopNews.title: Prime Minister Scott Morrison labels herd immunity a death sentence
weeklyTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison says the herd immunity approach to dealing with the COVID-19 virus is a "death sentence." Mr Morrison once again praised Australia's response to the coronavirus crisis, saying we've done very well compared to other nations. The Prime Minister also questioned the aggressive interrogation of a New South Wales health official at the Ruby Princess inquiry yesterday. Furthermore, the Prime Minister said he will continue to push for a global inquiry into the origins of COVID-19.

weeklyTopNews.title: Government releases proposed laws to underpin privacy protections for COVIDSafe app
weeklyTopNews.summary: The government has released a draft of its legislative backing to privacy and data protections for the COVIDSafe tracing app. It proposes to make it illegal for anyone to refuse a person without the app entry to a public place, ban them from an activity or refuse to buy or sell goods and services to them.The legislation would also make it an offence to access the data without proper authorisation and for the data to be stored anywhere outside of Australia, and says records of the Bluetooth "handshakes" a user's phone makes with people they come in close contact with must be deleted after 21 days or upon request. All offences have a maximum penalty of five years in jail, a $63,00 fine or both.

weeklyTopNews.title: Scott Morrison maps out Australia's path back to work
weeklyTopNews.summary: Australia has succeeded in containing the coronavirus outbreak but now needs to flatten a new "curve" of unemployment, Prime Minister Scott Morrison says. "We now need to get one million Australians back to work, that is the curve we need to address," Mr Morrison said. "As long as these restrictions are in place, they are costing our economy some $4 billion each week ... it certainly puts enormous pressure, as it should, on the timetable as we seek to move Australia back to that safe economy."

weeklyTopNews.title: Coles extends trading hours as panic-buying eases
weeklyTopNews.summary: Coles will extend trading hours at the majority of its stores. Almost 200 stores will begin trading from 6am, the supermarket giant confirmed this morning. The news comes as panic-buying across the country eases and stores begin replenishing empty shelves. Coles Chief Operations Officer, Matt Swindells said more stock on shelves and improved customer behaviour meant dedicated community hours could also be lifted.

weeklyTopNews.title: Jacinda Ardern says travel with Australia amid coronavirus pandemic could have 'huge advantages'
weeklyTopNews.summary: New Zealand's Prime Minister will tomorrow join the Australian Government's National Cabinet meeting to discuss the proposal. Australia and New Zealand have earned international praise for their success containing the COVID-19 outbreak, and both governments are now seriously contemplating lifting restrictions on flights between the countries. Ms Arden has declared that a trans-Tasman travel bubble would offer "huge advantages" as both countries intensify negotiations over possibly opening borders later this year. She would not be drawn on the possible timing, adding that there was no chance of flights resuming in the next few weeks.

weeklyTopNews.title: Queensland children to return to classroom in two stages - starting next week
weeklyTopNews.summary: Community kindy, prep as well as Years 1, 11 and 12 will return to classrooms in Queensland next Monday, May 11, as part of the state government plan to reopen schools in two stages over three weeks. Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk outlined the proposed agenda on Monday, with a reassessment to be done on May 15, before Years 2-10 were due to return to school on Monday, May 25. Chief health officer Dr Jeannette Young said the theory behind the two-stage school reopening was to get the pick-up and drop-off procedures, which were of most concern for potential COVID-19 transmission, perfected with the younger children while there were fewer students around and before the remaining students return.

weeklyTopNews.title: Scott Morrison urged to extend coronavirus assistance to one million 'vulnerable' temporary visa holders
weeklyTopNews.summary: Human rights and advocacy groups say Australia's more than one million temporary visa holders will be at risk of homelessness if the government does not extend its coronavirus relief measures to the most vulnerable. Almost 200 Australian community groups have signed an open letter to Prime Minister Scott Morrison, urging him to include more than one million refugees, asylum seekers and vulnerable communities in the government's coronavirus response.

weeklyTopNews.title: South Australian playgrounds to reopen after 11-day coronavirus-free streak
weeklyTopNews.summary: South Australia's Chief Public Health Officer, Nicola Spurrier, has recommended reopening parks, playgrounds and equipment from today after the state recorded 11 days without a new coronavirus case. Most — but not all — councils taped off playgrounds and fitness outdoor equipment during the pandemic. Dr Spurrier said reopening public play spaces was an indication of the community's efforts to slow the spread of coronavirus.

weeklyTopNews.title: Flight Centre waives cancellation fees after consumer watchdog threatens legal action
weeklyTopNews.summary: The consumer watchdog was preparing to launch court action against Flight Centre for charging $300 fees to process Covid-19 refunds before the company agreed to end the practice. Flight Centre angered many of its customers by charging the $300 fee to each person for each element of their trip that was cancelled due to the pandemic and associated travel restrictions. Flight Centre on Saturday announced it will no longer charge the fee if the travel provider cancels its service.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus app tracing capability not operational, despite 4 million downloads
weeklyTopNews.summary: More than 4 million people have downloaded the COVIDSafe app, but the information it collects is not yet available to state and territory health officials. He said the app was already logging users' close contacts, and that information could be accessed at a later date. The app will not be fully functional until states and territories finalise rules on privacy, and final IT testing is conducted.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus cases revealed in Victorian paramedic and cluster of Melbourne abattoir workers
weeklyTopNews.summary: The number of coronavirus cases in Victoria continues to inch up as a paramedic tests positive to the virus and health authorities investigate a cluster at a meat processing plant. The unnamed Melbourne meat processing plant has been temporarily closed after eight employees tested positive to coronavirus, including three in the past 24 hours. A spokesperson said there was nothing to indicate that the paramedic that tested positive had acquired the virus from patient contact, however, as a precaution, five paramedics who came into contact with them are also in isolation.

weeklyTopNews.title: Public health alert issued over new Queensland coronavirus case
weeklyTopNews.summary: A plane passenger returning to Brisbane from Melbourne has tested positive to COVID-19 overnight, triggering a public health alert. State health authorities are urgently tracing people the infected traveller was in contact with on Qantas flight QF614 from Melbourne to Brisbane on April 22. Those who travelled in rows 19, 20, 21, 22 and 23 are urged to contact Queensland Health.

weeklyTopNews.title: Australia's aged care centres to get $205 million to stay open during coronavirus crisis
weeklyTopNews.summary: Aged care providers will get another $205 million from the federal government to help them keep centres open to visitors during the coronavirus crisis. Providers will receive $900 per occupied bed under the new funding package, with regional centres offered $1,350 per resident. The national cabinet has also released a draft visitor access code, which is open for comment until May 11, to ensure families and carers can visit residents in nursing homes.

weeklyTopNews.title: Morrison says 'early mark' of eased restrictions depends on uptake of Covidsafe tracing app
weeklyTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison has offered Australians an “early mark” to ease Covid-19 restrictions next week while warning a return to normality will depend on uptake of the Covidsafe contact tracing app. Morrison also revealed that net overseas migration is down 30% and is expected to fall by 80% in 2020-21, both compared with 2018-19, in a sign the economic contraction from Covid-19 will last much longer than restrictions to social life. Treasury officials and the Reserve Bank both estimate that unemployment is set to top 10%.

weeklyTopNews.title: Marise Payne, Julie Bishop urge calm in tense relations with China over coronavirus origins
weeklyTopNews.summary: There are rising tensions between Australia and China, which began when Australia started pressing for an investigation into the origin of COVID-19. Foreign Minister Marise Payne says that global co-operation not economic coercion is the appropriate way to resolve the dispute over an international investigation into COVID-19. Ms Payne said she rejected the approach of ambassador Cheng Jingye, who floated a Chinese consumer boycott of Australian products in retaliation to tension over the probe, targeting the crucial agriculture, education and tourism markets.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus recovery: ACT becomes first state or territory to be free of known cases of COVID-19
weeklyTopNews.summary: The ACT has become the first Australian jurisdiction to be free of all known cases of COVID-19. After a total of 106 diagnoses and three deaths in the ACT, Jan Stoop, the last Canberran to test positive to coronavirus, has recovered. ACT Chief Health Officer Dr Kerryn Coleman welcomed the local elimination of the virus, and reiterated that the pandemic is ongoing, emphasising it is important not to undo the work that has been done.

weeklyTopNews.title: Australia's coronavirus restrictions are easing. Here's what you can do in your state this weekend
weeklyTopNews.summary: Millions of Australians are set to enjoy more freedoms over the coming days as COVID-19 restrictions are eased, but the rules are different in every state and territory. This article outlines the restrictions that have been dropped state-by-state.

weeklyTopNews.title: More than 1.3 million Australians on jobseeker as Senate inquiry calls for permanent increase to rate
weeklyTopNews.summary: More than 1.3 million people are now receiving unemployed benefits across the country, with that number expected to reach about 1.7 million in September. The government faces growing pressure to consider a permanent increase to the jobseeker payment, which has received a temporary $550 per fortnight boost for about six months.

weeklyTopNews.title: Prime Minister Scott Morrison flags easing of coronavirus restrictions in near future
weeklyTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrisonsaid Australia was "on the road back" to an economy safe from COVID-19 and that success could mean easing restrictions soon, noting that one of the most important tools to help fast-track restrictions being lifted was the Government's COVIDSafe tracing app. He also ruled out international travel restarting any time soon, with the potential exception of travel to New Zealand.

weeklyTopNews.title: Australians urged not to neglect mental health during 'pressure cooker' coronavirus pandemic
weeklyTopNews.summary: he government's top advisor on suicide prevention is urging Australians not to neglect their mental health during the coronavirus pandemic. Chief executive of the National Mental Health Commission Christine Morgan on Wednesday revealed new statistics showing the overall use of mental health services has been declining in Australia during the COVID-19 outbreak, which she speculated was due to people who would normally be using mental health services are not actually going out and doing those visits. Although the overall use of mental health services had declined, there had been an encouraging rise in the use of telehealth services such as Beyond Blue, Ms Morgan said.
